urn:contentItem:5J6R-88T1-JDVW-N45R-00000-00Barclays confirms Africa sale; ICE eyes LSE; Swedbank shoots down Danske talk2016-03-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:34ZLexisNexisExclusiveBarclays confirms Africa sale; ICE eyes LSE; Swedbank shoots down Danske talkMark Louie Bonayon

In today's Daily Dose: Barclays reports a widening full-year loss and says it will sell down its stake in Barclays Africa Group over the next two to three years; Intercontinental Exchange eyes a counterbid for London Stock Exchange Group; and Swedbank rejects rumors of a merger with Danske Bank.

UK AND IRELAND

Barclays to sell down Africa stake: Barclays Plctoday reported a fourth-quarter 2015 loss attributable to ordinary equity holders of the parent of £2.42 billion, compared to a loss of £1.68 billion a year ago. For the full year, the bank recorded a statutory attributable loss of £394 million, compared to a year-ago loss of £174 million. The company outlined plans to simplify the group to focus on two core divisions, Barclays UK and Barclays Corporate & International, as well as to sell down its stake in Barclays Africa Group Ltd.

* U.S. District Judge Victor Marrero in Manhattan, N.Y., yesterday said Barclays must face a proposed class-action lawsuit from California water utility Merced Irrigation District accusing the lender of illegally manipulating electricity prices in the western U.S., causing customers to pay inflated prices, costing at least $139.3 million, Reuters writes.

* Direct Line Insurance Group Plc today reported full-year 2015 after-tax profit of £580.4 million, up from £372.6 million a year earlier. Gross written premiums increased on a yearly basis to £3.15 billion from £3.10 billion.

* Jardine Lloyd Thompson Group Plc today posted full-year 2015 consolidated profit attributable to owners of the parent of £103.1 million, compared to £105.3 million in the year-ago period.

* Tullett Prebon Plc said today that the combined class 1 circular and prospectus relating to its proposed acquisition of the global hybrid voice broking and information business of ICAP Plcincluding ICAP's associated technology and broking platforms and certain of ICAP's joint ventures and associates will be published later today. Tullett Prebon said it continues to respond to the second request from the U.S. Department of Justice and to continue to work cooperatively with the DOJ in connection with its review of the transaction.

* Chirantan Barua, an analyst at Bernstein Research, said the low interest rate environment is making HSBC Holdings Plc's progressive dividend policy unsustainable, the Financial Times reports. Funding dividend payments from capital is too risky for HSBC as its buffer is relatively lower compared to those of U.K. counterparts, and the sharp slowdown in Hong Kong will also contribute to the dividend decline, Barua added.

* RSA Insurance Group Plc said today that it completed the sale of its operations in Brazil to Suramericana SA, the insurance unit of Grupo de Inversiones Suramericana SA. RSA expects the completion of the remaining disposals of its Latin American operations in Chile, Argentina, Mexico, Colombia and Uruguay to occur over the next six months.

* XL Group Plc said yesterday that it proposed to change the parent holding company's place of incorporation to Bermuda from Ireland. The company expects to submit the proposal for redomestication, along with related proposals, to its shareholders in the next several months and complete the shift in the third quarter.

* The U.K. government said in a report released yesterday that a British departure from the EU "could lead to up to a decade or more of uncertainty." The government said a vote to leave the bloc would be "the start, not the end, of a process," as such a move "would take an extended period to negotiate first our exit from the EU, secondly our future arrangements with the EU, and thirdly our trade deals with countries outside of the EU."

* Hiscox Ltd. said yesterday that it is creating a managing general agent this year to underwrite risks outside of the company's underwriting appetite on behalf of other insurers, providing them with a flow of business and earning the company fees and profit commission.

* The U.K. Prudential Regulation and Financial Conduct authorities said yesterday that they informed the European Banking Authority that they will comply with all aspects of its guidelines on sound remuneration policies, except for the provision that the bonus cap must be applied to all firms subject to the EU's Capital Requirements Directive. The regulators said the all-firms approach fails to recognize the different incentives and consequences for risk-taking across all CRD-regulated firms. The regulators will continue to require smaller firms to determine an appropriate ratio between fixed and variable remuneration while not applying the bonus cap.

* The FCA said yesterday that investment management firms should reassess liquidity management as it is "particularly timely" to do so given current market conditions. The FCA said investment managers should fully and clearly disclose to fund investors liquidity risks and the tools available to the fund to manage those risks, such as swing pricing, deferred redemption and suspension.

* The U.K. Competition and Markets Authority found "no strong evidence" that a tax surcharge on bank profits would deter new lenders, stifle their growth or force small banks to leave the market, the Financial Times and Reuters report. "The six largest retail banks will continue to pay higher effective rates of tax than smaller banks," the regulator said, despite claims from challenger banks that the new tax will hit their profits.

* Lancashire Holdings Ltd. said yesterday that three underwriters for unit Cathedral Underwriting Ltd., Simon King, Mark Wilson and Nicholas Destro, tendered notices to resign, which have been accepted.

GERMANY, SWITZERLAND AND AUSTRIA

ICE plans LSE counterbid: NYSE operator Intercontinental Exchange Inc. plans a counterbid for London Stock Exchange Group Plc in an attempt to avert the latter's merger with Deutsche Börse AG, Bloomberg News reports. Meanwhile, Reuters writes that French Economy Minister Emmanuel Macron said the LSE-Deutsche Börse deal would cause "competition issues," especially for smaller exchange operators in Europe and should also be assessed in the light of the possibility of Britain leaving the EU.

* Swiss Life Holding Ltd. today posted an increase in full-year 2015 net profit attributable to equity holders to CHF872 million from CHF814 million a year ago. The company's board of directors will propose an increased dividend of CHF8.50 per share, compared to CHF6.50 per share in 2014.

* Deutsche Bank AG's buyback of $740 million of its own dollar-denominated bonds, a move aimed at boosting confidence in its financial solidity, was significantly below the $2 billion cap on the offer, Bloomberg News reports.

* UniCredit Bank AG has sued former top executives, including its former CFO Rolf Friedhofen, for damages amounting to more than (EURO)140 million from illegal "cum-ex" dividend deals, Handelsblatt reports.

* Swiss National Bank President Thomas Jordan said the bank would consider reducing the deposit amount for corporate banks exempt from negative interest rates should the central bank further loosen its monetary policy, the Handelzeitung notes.

* Ahead of their planned merger, DZ Bank AG and WGZ Bank are close to finalizing a five-year redundancy package including employment protection for up to 1,000 employees expected to lose their jobs, Handelsblatt reports.

* Liechtensteinische Landesbank AG in a revision of its unaudited 2015 interim financial report reduced net profit for the first half of 2015 by CHF3.4 million to CHF40.8 million owing to an adjustment in income from the sale of the majority shareholding in swisspartners Investment Network AG in March last year.

FRANCE AND BENELUX

Achmea takes (EURO)120M-plus storm hit: Achmea BV today reported full-year 2015 net profit attributable to holders of equity instruments of the company of (EURO)383 million, compared to (EURO)14 million a year ago. Executive Board Chairman Willem van Duin said positive developments at the company's pension and life, banking and international activities and higher investment results contributed to a higher result, adding that compensation for storm damage reduced income by more than (EURO)120 million.

* La Banque Postale is to launch a payment system based on voice recognition in the summer, Les Echos reports. La Tribune says the bank is trying to capitalize on the growth of e-commerce in France.

* AXA's newly created AXA Wealth subsidiary is recruiting for the 130 posts it will fill at its headquarters in Bordeaux, France, Sud Ouest reports.

* BNP Paribas Fortis SA CEO Max Jadot tells De Tijd that banks have much to fear from big tech companies such as Google, Apple, Facebook and Amazon. Jadot said that if Facebook were to connect WhatsApp to a payment service, it would enjoy huge economies of scale, although he nevertheless said banks are too complex to disappear.

SOUTHERN EUROPE

Santander gets Brazil capital boost: Banco Santander SA said it revised the way it calculates operational risk at Banco Santander (Brasil) SA, slashing the group's risk-weighted assets by (EURO)7.8 billion and boosting its common equity Tier 1 capital ratio by roughly 14 basis points, Bloomberg News reports. The ECB authorized the bank to apply the "alternative standardized approach" to its Brazilian unit to calculate operational-risk capital requirements.

* Il Messaggero writes that Banca Popolare di Milano Scarl and Banco Popolare Società Cooperativa are working on a new plan for the governance and doubtful loans of the merged entity whereby they plan to sell over a period of three years some (EURO)7 billion worth of nonperforming loans, with a possibility of selling a further (EURO)3 billion in 2020.

* UniCredit SpA asked the Antitrust Authority to remove some of the measures imposed following its merger with Capitalia in 2007, MF writes.

* Banca Popolare di Vicenza SCpA shareholders called on the Cariverona Foundation to take part in the lender's upcoming capital increase, MF writes. Reuters notes that Popolare di Vicenza filed for admission to trading on the Milan stock exchange.

* Two lists were presented for the renewal of the board of Credito Valtellinese SC, one with the current management and the other represented by the Go Credito association, MF writes.

* Greek banks are committing to reduce nonperforming loans by 10% this year, Naftemporiki reports after meetings between Greek banks and the Bank of Greece. The aim is to reach eurozone levels within seven years. Meanwhile, Kathimerini writes that Greek banks are expected to report increased provisions in their fourth-quarter 2015 results.

* Alpha Bank AE and Eurobank Ergasias SA announced today the conclusion of the acquisition of Alpha Bank's Bulgarian branch operations by Eurobank Bulgaria AD.

NORDIC COUNTRIES

Swedbank rejects Danske rumors: Swedbank AB has rejected rumors that it is in talks about a merger with Danske Bank A/S, Svenska Dagbladet reports. Swedbank's investor relations manager, Gregori Karamouzis, said Swedbank "is not discussing any kind of merger - with Danske Bank or any other bank."

* Danish pension companyPFA Pension Forsikrings A/S is reducing its staff by 63 full-time positions, Børsen reports. The cuts are linked to CEO Allan Polack's plans to make PFA more efficient and cut costs by 250 million kroner by 2020.

EASTERN EUROPE

RBI looks anew at Polish sale: Raiffeisen Bank International AG is once again probing the possibility of selling its Polish unit, Raiffeisen Bank Polska SA, and is looking for ways to remove the lender's Swiss franc-denominated loan portfolio from its balance sheet, Puls Biznesu reports. The potential sale could be an opportunity for Polish insurer PZU SA, which wants to become more involved in the Polish banking sector, the newspaper notes.

* First Deputy Governor Alexei Simanovsky said the Russian central bank is considering allowing investors holding over 1% stakes in failed banks to participate in financial recovery programs launched for such lenders, Vedomosti and Kommersant report. He said this would be another way for the regulator to save on bank bailouts, which have cost Russia more than 1 trillion rubles since the end of 2008.

* Fitch Ratings is likely to maintain its branch in Moscow rather than set up a separate subsidiary, as required by Russian law, which means that the company would have to stop providing national ratings, but would still be able to issue international ratings for local firms, RBK Daily and Kommersant report, citing Bloomberg News. RBK Daily notes that S&P and Moody's could take a similar route.

* Bank Ochrony Srodowiska SA plans to offer between 300 million Polish zlotys and 600 million zlotys in new shares in a private subscription, hoping to bolster its capital by at least 400 million zlotys in order to meet increased capital requirements and foster organic growth, Rzeczpospolita reports.

* KBC Group NV plans to invest heavily into Czech subsidiary Ceskoslovenská obchodní banka a.s. in the near future to make the bank a leader on the Czech market, Lidove Noviny reports, citing KBC CEO Johan Thijs.

IN OTHER PARTS OF THE WORLD

* MetLife Inc. agreed to sell its U.S. retail adviser force, MetLife Premier Client Group, along with its affiliated broker/dealer, MetLife Securities Inc., and certain related assets to Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Co. for approximately $300 million, subject to customary adjustments.

* The Indian government unveiled a number of proposals designed to strengthen the local financial sector, including a roadmap for the consolidation of public sector banks, The Times of India reported. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley said the government will release a roadmap for consolidation of public sector banks while presenting the 2016-2017 budget to the parliament.

* The Reserve Bank of Australia today kept its cash rate unchanged at 2% for a 10th straight month, Reuters reports. Governor Glenn Stevens said policymakers "judged that there were reasonable prospects for continued growth in the economy."

China Life Insurance Co. Ltd. said yesterday that it agreed to purchase 3,648,276,645 shares of China Guangfa Bank Co. Ltd. from Citigroup Inc. and IBM Credit LLC for a total of 23.31 billion yuan. Citi is selling 3,080,479,452 shares, or a 20% stake in China Guangfa Bank, while IBM Credit is selling 567,797,193 shares of the Chinese lender.

NOW FEATURED ON SNL

No surefire (EURO)25B merger for Deutsche Börse, LSE: Deutsche Börse and LSE are courting each other once more, but they remain far from certain that this time they will make it to the altar, not least because of regulatory concerns.

Germany's sparkassen eye possible mergers: Germany's cooperative banks have led the way by merging their central institutes and some sparkassen leaders are talking about mergers.

Jyske Bank looks to grow mortgage book despite market challenges, says CFO: While the Danish banking sector grapples with low credit demand, Jyske Bank is looking to grow its mortgage book by repatriating loans from Nykredit, Jyske Bank CFO Birger Krøgh Nielsen told S&P Global Market Intelligence.

Rich Lovie, Arno Maierbrugger, Brian McCulloch, Kees Pijnappels, Yael Schrage, Praxilla Trabattoni, Mike Hatzidakis, Esben Svendsen, Beata Fojcik and Ali Kayalar contributed to this report.

The Daily Dose has an editorial deadline of 7 a.m. London time. Some external links may require a subscription.

urn:contentItem:53V0-3G81-DYG3-13TD-00000-00Barclays PLC at Barclays Capital Global Financial Services Conference - Final2011-09-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:34ZLexisNexis091311a4199812.712Barclays PLCat Barclays CapitalGlobal Financial Services Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Larry Kantor Barclays PLC- Head of Research * Bob Diamond Barclays PLC- Chief Executive * Chris Lucas Barclays PLC- Group Finance Director * Jerry del Missier Barclays PLC- Co-Chief Executive of Barclays Capital, Co-Chief Executive of Corporate & Investment Banking * Rich Ricci Barclays PLC- Co-Chief Executive of Barclays Capital, Co-Chief Executive of Corporate & Investment Banking

Presentation

LARRY KANTOR, HEAD OF RESEARCH, BARCLAYS PLC: So, I'm Larry Kantor. I'm the Head of Research for Barclays Capital. I want to welcome everybody here to the lunch at our eighth annual financial services conference.

I'd like to introduce Bob. You probably all know Bob started Barclays Capitalin 1996 basically from scratch and he instilled a culture at the firm that persists to this day that has worked very well for everybody who's worked at the firm and has, I think, been the main reason for our success. This culture's all about meritocracy, it's all about execution and it's all about the focus on servicing our clients.

I got to Barclays in 2003. At that time, the objective was to be the best fixed income house and risk manager. We had a little over 5,000 people, I think, globally at Barclays Capital. I have to say I think at the time, most investors were pretty skeptical that we'd be able to achieve that objective. In the end, we did succeed in that objective and built top three franchises in rates and commodities and in FX.

Then, of course, we went through the financial crisis. We not only survived as one of the only major banks not to take even a dime from any government but we really thrived and acquired a first-rate global equities and banking franchise and a much bigger presence in the US with the merger with Lehman. We have a new objective and that's to be the premier global investment bank. As a Barclays employee for over eight years, I've learned to take these objectives very seriously because we're serious about them.

I would venture to say in my opinion, this integration between Barclays and Lehman will go down as the most successful integration in the history of financial services, although I'd be the first to admit that the bar is pretty low -- hasn't been a lot of great ones. You may say it was lucky Lehman landed in our laps. Surely luck plays a role in everything in financial markets -- in fact, you might say everything in life. I would remind everybody that at that time -- which was, if you all remember, mid-September 2008 -- there were no other bidders.

I'll also just tell you a very brief story about Bob, which he probably doesn't even remember. I was asked in -- I think it was 2006, to make a presentation before the Board at an off-site and I got to see the long-range plans of the firm and I was amazed how much revenue was projected for the United States. I saw Bob the next day in the office and I said, "There's no way we can achieve that organically." He said, "Right." So I started talking to him about possibilities, just my own ideas. He basically said, "Too expensive. We're going to wait." Well, I think that was in 2006 a pretty prescient thing to say.

So I'll just end by saying that not just speaking for me as a Barclays employee but I think all the Barclays employees in the room and at large -- and I know a lot of them -- we all have tremendous confidence in Bob and the senior management team, many of which are sitting right here. We all know that this is going to be incredibly challenging -- is an incredibly challenging environment from a number of perspectives.

BOB DIAMOND, CHIEF EXECUTIVE, BARCLAYS PLC: I was going to let you stay up here, Larry. You're on a roll. I want to repeat your "thank you," Larry, to Jason Goldberg and the financials team and to Bruce Harting who is a co-founder of this event and has now shifted gears from the research team into the investment banking [fig] team. So to Jason and Bruce and Larry, for all that you do, this is a fantastic conference and it's my honor to be here.

Well, I want to thank you all for joining us today, as I said, at the Barclays CapitalFinancial Services Conference. There are three topics that I'm going to try and cover today. I've chosen them because I recognize that our stock trades at a significant discount to our tangible equity and I do not believe that that is justified.

So I want to directly address the concerns that I know people have, concerns that have been heightened by the fact that we are operating in an environment that lacks certainty, an environment that lacks confidence. This includes lack of certainty about regulation, especially in the UK, where the Independent Commission on Banking published their final report just yesterday; lack of confidence about the eurozone and our exposures there; and concerns as to whether we will be able to hit our targeted return on equity of 13% by 2013 in the face of new regulation, challenging market conditions, and slowing economic growth.

While market conditions are challenging and I understand the concerns people have, we are confident about our position at Barclays. Let me take this opportunity to explain why, starting with regulation. The Independent Commission on Banking published its final report yesterday after 15 months of careful deliberation. This publication represents a welcome step towards the greater clarity that banks need to be able to operate with confidence. I know the major question you have is what the cost of this will be for Barclays but as you will understand, there's still a lot of work to be done here.

The report calls for changes in UK law, changes in international law and coordination with international regulation. There are many steps yet to be taken, and until we know the full details, it is difficult to quantify the impact. So let me focus instead on the key provisions of the report.

First, we welcome the ICB's recognition that the benefits of diversification in banking models should be retained, both for the good of clients and for the internal synergies that exist. As the Chancellor said, the goal has to be for Britain to be the home of successful international banks. It's important that our shareholders will continue to be able to access both retail and institutional earnings.

We also welcome the fact that the report's recommendations leave flexibility to determine the final implementation -- the final details of implementation. This allows for the definition of the ring fence to be aligned with the shape of our retail and corporate banking businesses and with the work we have already done on recovery and resolution plans. As we've already said, ring fencing is not our first choice but we believe we can make it work. Looking at the capital requirements, for example, the requirement for a core Tier 1 ratio of 10% in the ring-fenced entity was as expected. As you already know, at the half year Barclays' core Tier 1 ratio -- Barclays' core equity ratio was 11%.

The report also calls for primary loss-absorbing capital of 17% to 20%. Currently our Tier 1 and Tier 2 ratios amount to 17% and our total potential loss-absorbing capital is more than double that.

The timeline for implementation, which runs until 2019, is critical for banks to accommodate the changes while continuing to support the economy. Barclays has a very strong track record of adapting its business model to deliver for its shareholders and this timeline gives us confidence in being able to continue to do just that.

Recall that in 2008, we signalled we would get ahead of regulatory change by ensuring that we have a strong capital position. Our core Tier 1 ratio has doubled since then to 11%, our Tier 1 capital has grown to 13.5% and our total capital, including Tier 2, now stands at 17%.

One reason for this is our own ability to generate capital. Since 2008, we've generated GBP8.8 billion of equity and virtually the entire increase in our core Tier 1 ratio in the last 18 months has resulted from our underlying profit performance.

We've also reduced leverage to 20x and our surplus liquidity has increased to GBP145 billion. GBP85 billion of that pool is cash held with central banks, GBP25 billion is in UK government bonds and a further GBP24 billion is in other government bonds including Switzerland, the US, and Japan.

Despite market volatility, our funding position is very strong. We've raised GBP54 billion in term liabilities over the past 18 months and we priced a EUR2 billion three-year covered bond at 52 basis points over mid swaps as recently as August 31. So we're accessing funding cost effectively, even though the market has tightened.

Our liquidity stress tests show that even in the worst case scenario, where the wholesale markets close completely, we have a significant buffer period before taking any management action. In addition, our surplus liquidity pool covers an entire year of wholesale maturities. In short, Barclays today continues to operate with rock solid capital and rock solid liquidity.

Moving on to the eurozone, we recognize there are concerns about Greece, Italy, Spain, Portugal and Ireland. So we have given a detailed breakdown of our assets in these markets in terms of the businesses they relate to, the nature of the risk, and how we manage that risk. To summarize, GBP44 billion of our exposure --- the majority -- relates to retail banking activities. This is almost all mortgages, mainly on first homes with low loan-to-value ratios, in Spain and Italy and in Portugal. Our corporate assets total about GBP14 billion. We took substantial provisions upfront on our corporate portfolio. Our impairment charges are now declining and we expect that to continue.

Our sovereign exposure of GBP11.6 billion is all fair valued. 70% of this is held to hedge interest rate risk relating to our local businesses. Over half of that has a remaining life of under two years and is being replaced by swaps. 30% of our sovereign exposure is in our trading and derivative portfolio, resulting from our role as a leading primary dealer, market maker and liquidity provider to our clients. The remaining assets, less than GBP7 billion, relate to financial institutions and normal interbank activity.

A significant part of this is the strong financial institutions with administrative centers in Ireland but with little Irish exposure. Keep in mind that while it is booked in Ireland, the real risk is to the strong parent company.

You'll notice that I have not mentioned Greece. Our exposure there is minimal.

In summary, our exposures in these markets are not speculative. They are largely in retail banking, they are largely secured and we're managing our risks carefully. So we're confident about the assets that we own and the values at which they're held.

Of course, confidence will not be restored until the EU sovereign debt issue is resolved. This is the most critical issue weighing on the markets right now. The opportunity for Europe is clear -- a big, deep, liquid sovereign debt market with all the safety and security characteristics of the US Treasury market, underpinning a European corporate funding market and driving economic growth. The way to achieve this is through greater fiscal integration. I believe the debate will increasingly address how and when we get there, not if we get there.

As the uncertainty continues, we remain focused on four key priorities at Barclays -- capital strength, returns, income growth and citizenship. Each of these is critical to our ability to succeed in this environment and we have a strong, experienced management team committed to executing on each and every one.

I've talked about our strong capital position, so I want to move on now to talk about returns. We set a target this February to generate a return on equity of 13% by 2013. With greater certainty, now that the ICB has published their report, we reiterate that target.

Though we're just eight months into our journey and we still have a long way to go, there are signs of good progress in our underlying numbers. Our adjusted return on equity rose to 9.1% in the first half from just below 7%. Our return on tangible equity grew to just under 11%. This was driven by a 24% profit growth in the first half, excluding PPI and own credit.

Our three world-class businesses --- Retail and Business Banking in the UK, Barclaycard and Barclays Capital--- are businesses that operate in the very top tier of their industry, businesses that have scale, have technology, have brand and have customer depth and breadth. All three delivered an adjusted return on equity above 13% in the first half this year.

As you know, we apply a core Tier 1 ratio of 10% to all of our businesses. UK Retail Banking reported a return on equity of 15%, at Barclaycard it was 16%, and Barclays Capitalgenerated a return of 15%, even in a soft trading environment. Together, these three businesses account for two thirds of our risk-weighted assets, two thirds of our capital.

In addition, we have two businesses that have the potential to become top tier, Wealth and Africa. I'll talk about these later in relation to income growth. Both show continued progress.

Then there are two businesses where we recognize that we have serious work to do, Corporate Banking and Retail and Business Banking in continental Europe. Barclays Corporate returned to profitability in the first half of this year. That is very significant improvement on the negative return last year, though clearly we still have much further to go.

Europe Retail and Business Banking was loss-making, due to the costs of restructuring that business. In particular, we are reducing headcount and the size of our branch network in Spain. The business now has strong leadership and is much better shaped for this environment. It will return to profitability in the second half and deliver positive returns going forward.

Disciplined cost management is also critical to delivering returns and will give us the flexibility to navigate the incredibly challenging market conditions. We held costs flat in the first half and expect to deliver a reduction of GBP250 million for the full year, net of restructuring. We believe we will comfortably exceed our savings target for 2013 of GBP1 billion because we are running Barclays today in a more integrated and in a more efficient way.

Our third execution priority, income growth, is also an important part of delivering returns. Though the environment has been challenging, those areas where we have been investing are beginning to deliver. At Barclays Wealth, we are in the second year of a five-year investment program. In 2010, the first year, revenues grew 18%. This year, first-half income grew 12% and we're continuing to operate ahead of plan.

We launched One Africa at the beginning of July and Maria Ramos is now CEO of the Africa region. Total income was up 7.5% when we combine revenues from all of our activities across Africa. As you know, we have top tier businesses in many African markets, and our One Africa strategy will deliver the entire capabilities of Barclays in an integrated way across the continent.

Within Barclays Capital, while overall income was down, there was good growth in the businesses that have been targeted to build out globally. Equity and Prime Services grew 5%. Investment Banking was up 11%. Market share in both is growing. We are also pleased with the strong performance in UK Retail and Business Banking, where income grew 4% in the first half as we continue to upgrade the customer experience by investing in our branches, in our technology and in our people.

Our fourth priority is citizenship and for me this embraces several important elements. It's about the way we behave, in particular the way we treat customers and clients. It's about the way we help our customers and clients create jobs and economic growth. It's about the way we support the communities in which we work.

Operating with integrity lies at the very heart of our focus on citizenship. We know that trust in this industry has been damaged in recent years. We know we do not always get things right for every customer. When we get them wrong, we apologize and we put them right. That is our commitment.

In a challenging environment, we have continued to do all we can to support job creation and business growth by standing by our clients. In the first half, Barclays Capitalwas the leading book runner for debt capital markets globally. So at a time when we see a lack of certainty and a lack of confidence, we help clients raise more financing in public debt markets around the world than any other bank.

Here in the US, Barclays Capitalis a leader in taking companies public, enabling them to raise funds they need to invest in their businesses and to create jobs. In the United Kingdom, we held over 75,000 meetings with business clients in the first six months this year. We supported the startup of 50,000 new businesses. We approved a new loan to UK SME every four minutes.

We also continue to help the communities in which we live and work. In the first half, we supported more than 45,000 of our colleagues at Barclays as they worked for causes that they believe in. We did this by giving them time and matching their fundraising efforts. We care about being good citizens not just because it is the right thing to do, but because trust underpins our relationships with customers and clients. Trust underpins our reputation and our brand. Trust underpins the delivery of sustainable return for shareholders.

We recognize that markets have been greatly unnerved by fears about the future of the eurozone and by the prospect of low economic growth. Against that background of uncertainty and lack of confidence, we are very, very clear about our priorities. We have strengthened our capital position. We are investing selectively for growth. We are focused on returns.

Our three world-class businesses, which together account for two thirds of our capital, delivered a return on equity of 15% or more in the first half of this year. We're investing in our two businesses with potential to become top tier and they are already generating strong income growth and we have made progress with those businesses that need work. In short, we are on track to deliver a return on equity of 13% by 2013.

In recent times, the valuations of large, well-capitalized UK headquartered banks have been discounted due to uncertainty. Yet the UK is ahead of many others in addressing the challenge of reducing public debt. It's working hard on passing the mantle of growth from the public to the private sector and it does not face the challenges that we see in Europe.

The UK has the advantage of its own currency and of fiscal autonomy. With this week's report from the Independent Commission on Banking, we are close to resolving regulatory uncertainties in the United Kingdom. In times of stress, rock-solid capital, liquidity and funding is a strong differentiator. It may now be time to look at well-capitalized, UK headquartered banks in a new light.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: You mentioned financial integration and you thought for the European countries to move closer together. Can you expand upon how you think this situation plays out and what do you mean by that, that you think is the end game?

BOB DIAMOND: I would love to, but most of what I've learned about this, I've learned from Jerry. So rather than tell you what Jerry thinks, I'll let Jerry tell you what Jerry thinks.

JERRY DEL MISSIER: I think you've got short-term issues and then structurally the long term. I think it's important to understand that it was always going to require a crisis of profound magnitude to really force Europe to take the next step towards fiscal consolidation. Because at the end of the day, it involves a loss of sovereignty and for the first 10 years of its existence, I think everyone's been able to have a free lunch. The Germans have had 60% of their export market locked into a currency that was too rich for them and the peripheral countries got the benefit of lower rates without actually having to behave fiscally responsibly.

So we're now kind of going through this having had dinner, now they're dividing the check and it's going to take a while to work through this. I mean, this process that Bob talked about will take years and it will be done in the face of social unrest and it will have to require, in essence, a ceding of sovereignty over fiscal issues towards much, much more centralized control over budgets. I think it's going to require some very difficult decisions about the nature of the social welfare state, which is a very, very big deal in Europe and these are not things that will sort themselves out quickly. So if we're expecting that in the next month they're going to announce fiscal union, I mean, it's just not going to happen. This is going to take time. So we should understand that.

I think in the short run, you have really the issue of somehow needing to bring stability back to the sovereign debt markets. Part of that is dealing with Greece in a way that doesn't create contagion elsewhere. Part of it is, I think, continued intervention so that the countries other than Greece are able to access debt at low rates that don't become an impediment to growth.

Then I think, frankly, part of it is also that you'll see a more growth-oriented approach to monetary policy. It would surprise me if that wasn't one of the things that came out of this. This whole challenge has been exacerbated by the fact that it's happening while we've seen growth slowing in the US and growth slowing in Europe and we kind of -- there needs to be a focus on getting growth back in the system to help some of these countries deal with their issues.

So look for it to be long-term. Don't underestimate the commitment. This is all about peace and prosperity and creating a sustainable Europe. You can expect to see continued brinksmanship between the central authorities and the member states. But I think ultimately it will head in the right direction. If there are issues where banks -- there needs to be recapitalization and I think a stability of markets allows that to happen. I think it plays itself out in the near term and then it will be an issue that we'll have to watch over a period of years.

BOB DIAMOND: To put kind of what's the ultimate goal that Jerry mentioned in context, I think this ages me quite a bit, but I recall working on the first ECU bond in 1992 for the Bank of England. From the beginning of the single currency in 1999, for those of us that were in the markets then, the transformation to have a market other than the US dollar market -- other than the US located here, because the euro bond market, if you recall, while that was a big liquid dollar market, it was for sovereigns and supernationals. It wasn't for corporates. Corporates really went to the US market.

One of the things that's really driven the economic growth over the last 15 years in Europe has been a big, liquid, deep sovereign market that's allowed corporates to price, whether it's in bond deals or equity deals, as Jerry said. So the vested interest away from a lot of the issues that are getting the publication, but having a big, liquid, deep sovereign debt market with the same safety and security characteristics of the US Treasury, allowing you to price corporate deals and get liquid corporate deals and get financial institution deals, which you can't get off today.

The stakes are very high for Europe here, in terms of their economic future and in terms of the financial markets existing in this time zone. So I think sometimes we jump to the conclusion that there is a crisis and the conclusion has to be fall apart as opposed to stay together. So for the Chancellor and the Prime Minister to have been out there early in reducing spending and focusing on getting the deficit and the debt down, they've had some pressure and they need the economic growth to get going. But the economy's going to go only one way if you're reducing public spending and that's to pass the mantle of growth to the private sector, which in the UK is very healthy as it is in the US -- a lot of cash on the balance sheet; even small businesses have a lot of cash. A little bit of certainty around bank capital, so banks can be more active and more confident, and a little bit more confidence in the economy and the direction of the administration could go a long way, together with the independence of the currency in the fiscal integration.

So I feel a lot better that there's been -- in a funny way, even though the report isn't that much different than what I would have discussed with everyone here over the last 12 months, I feel a big cloud has been lifted off the UK. I think that's going to be very helpful to our franchise and our business.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: (Inaudible question - microphone inaccessible).

BOB DIAMOND: I already said yes. Can I just get that one? Sorry.

This better be good now.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Oh, I know. The pressure is on.

BOB DIAMOND: A lot of pressure.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: It's actually about risk-weighted assets and the investment bank and I think you've talked about this, so forgive me for not remembering. But did you tell us what the new RWA, the projected RWA would be at the investment bank? The increase -- I think there was meant to be some offsets, some mitigating measures. Can you just review that?

CHRIS LUCAS: We can touch on that. We've given you the estimates of Basel 2.5, which is the market risk RWAs that come on at the end of this year. That's about GBP40 billion and we showed you the impact on our core Tier 1 ratio at the 30th of June. So to go beyond that into Basel 3, we've given some views -- we did so at the investor day -- in terms of the size of growth of RWAs and some views about management actions. But we said that's, by very nature, a broad estimate as we continue to refine the methodologies and the approach to the management of RWAs.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: And what were --?

BOB DIAMOND: We'll follow up with you. I think we need to get -- but if you want to follow up with Chris after this, we can do that. Jason, thank you for everything you've done to put this on and David, thank you very much. Thank you for listening.
