urn:contentItem:5X33-N3T1-JB20-G1W7-00000-00Barclays PLC at Barclays Global Financial Services Conference - Final2019-09-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:34ZLexisNexis090919a12728630.730Barclays PLC at Barclays Global Financial Services Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* James Edward Staley

Barclays PLC - Group CEO & Executive Director

Conference Call Participants

* Jason Michael Goldberg

Barclays Bank PLC, Research Division - MD & Senior Equity Analyst

Presentation

JASON MICHAEL GOLDBERG, MD & SENIOR EQUITY ANALYST, BARCLAYS BANK PLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: Thank you for attending our 17th Annual Global Financial Services Conference. There's more people in this room now than we had this morning. So those I don't know or haven't met, I'm Jason Goldberg. I cover the U.S. large-cap bank stocks here at Barclays. I'm told, we had over 200 companies. This is the largest financial services sell-side conference ever. So thank you for turning up and helping make this a success so far. To maximize our time this afternoon, I'll save a lot of thank-yous that go into making this conference a success until Wednesday and leave time for today's lunch keynote speaker.

In Barclays, we have a perfect company for a keynote presentation at a global financial services conference as it bills itself as a transatlantic consumer, corporate and investment bank with a global reach. With us today is Jes Staley, Group CEO of Barclays. And my boss's, boss's, boss's boss. Jes has been at the Barclays and in this role for about 3 years and 3 quarters, and I can personally attest to the positive impact he's had on the organization, particularly not in the smoothest of macro times.

I'm going to come over, and with -- Jes and I will do a keynote fireside chat.

JAMES EDWARD STALEY, GROUP CEO & EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, BARCLAYS PLC: Before you start, if I can just say, this is a record attendance we understand for any financial services conference. And if we can get the mic adjusted and that's very much a function of Jason, and his impact for us is outstanding because there's nothing better than being a financial institution and hosting the best financial service conference in the industry. So congratulations, Jason.

The other thing I want to say is almost everyone in this room is our client, and we've made it a cornerstone of our strategy to be one of the more successful bulge bracket investment banks anchored in New York and London. And you are very much a part of that foundation, and the business you do with us every single day leads us to the strategic goal that we set out for ourselves in March 2016. So it's an honor to be here with all of you. You're extremely important to Barclays, and we appreciate your support, and we're glad we can bring everyone together in a conference as successful as what Jason you're writing here with everyone.

Questions and Answers

JASON MICHAEL GOLDBERG: Thank you, Jes. Appreciate that. This morning, in this room, we kicked off with former Dallas Fed Chair Richard Fisher, and he clearly talked to the uncertain macro backdrop globally that we're seeing. I guess how are you thinking about Barclays today as you approach some of your key milestones with the RoTE targets of greater than 9% this year and greater than 10% next?

JAMES EDWARD STALEY: Well, we feel very confident in our profit target for this year of 9% or better. For the first 6 months, we delivered 9.4%, and in 5 of the last 6 months, we've delivered over 9%. So it's not a big leap to basically repeat what we've been delivering for over a year now. And there are a lot of macroeconomic headwinds and tailwinds. Part of our diversified model is to be both in the U.K. and outside the U.K. So a little over 40% of our revenues are dollar-based. When the sterling weakens like this, given our cost and revenue mix, that's a headwind for us. If we -- if you drop the sterling exchange rate by 10 points for the GBP 1.20 to GBP 1.10, that adds about GBP 250 million to GBP 300 million of additional PBT for the bank. So with the diversified model, macro trends will both help us and hurt us.

But there really is some new things happening, particularly in Europe, that I think we all have to be very mindful of. We had been in this room 10 years ago, and we've done one of these polls that Jason does that said if we had a 10-year growth rate in the economy of the U.S. and Europe and if 10 years from now, we have the lowest unemployment rate virtually in the history of the United States and in the history of the U.K., where would the 10-year be -- rate be? And I bet almost all of us would've had up on the poll somewhere between 4% and 6%. But at minimum, I think that we would've had a 4 handle. And now we're looking, and you have $20 trillion of sovereign debt with the absolute negative interest. The U.K. 10-year gilt is trading at under 50 basis points. And in the U.S., as Fisher talked about, we're cutting interest rates in the U.S.

So there is a phenomenon going out there where the markets just do not feel a sense of concern around inflation and wage pressure. So we, in the bank industry, particularly in Europe, particularly those banks that are in absolute negative markets, it's a real challenge to run a bank facing virtually flat interest rates. We're all going to feel that. And then the challenges sort of double down when you have a flat yield curve. The flip side, I think -- and I think we'll see that in the U.K. -- is I think people are warming to the fact that the response to drive economic recovery when you're near or at 0 interest rates, it's not monetary, but rather it's fiscal. And really, what happened in the United States to drive the economic growth for the last number of years was United States government basically became far less worried given where interest rates were in running a fiscal deficit. There are 2 countries that I think are very focused on the fiscal deficits despite having the lowest interest rates in the market, one being Germany, a really big issue, but also the U.K. The U.K.'s deficit to GDP is about 1%, one of the lowest of any G20 country. And as I said, our 10-year gilt is below 50 basis points. I would argue that if you can borrow on a real basis at negative interest rates, you should be far less worried about your fiscal deficit and far more focused on your fiscal policies driving economic growth. And I think that's one of the things in the conversation that we've had, and I think is embraced by the current Chancellor in the U.K. and by the current Prime Minister. So as we look at the issue of Brexit and whatnot, I think we feel that there's some macro challenges in front of us, these would be interest rates, macro advantages for us in terms of currency and macro advantages for us, if in fact, the British Government is about to apply a fiscal stimulus to its economy and as everyone noticed in the United States, the most powerful way for fiscal stimulus to immediately turbocharge an economy is through tax cuts. So I would watch that.

JASON MICHAEL GOLDBERG: Interesting. You made a comment about Barclays' diversified model. Can you maybe just talk to why you think this is so important in the current macro environment?

JAMES EDWARD STALEY: We've all gone through a lot of financial markets' ups and downs and we get -- and we -- and sort of our views of the markets are very much embedded in the history that we've lived through. To my mind, in 2008 and 2009, one of the biggest lessons was the countercyclicality between a wholesale bank and a consumer bank. If you think back, we were at JP Morgan on the operating committee back then. In 2008, investment bank lost some $24 billion at JP Morgan, the worst performance ever in the -- in their investment bank. But the bank made money every quarter because the consumer bank had actually quite a profitable year in 2008. In 2009, Morgan's credit card business and home equity loan business lost $30 billion, but the bank made money every quarter because the investment bank had a record year.

One of the few other banks to through the financial crisis in 2008, 2009, making money every single quarter was Barclays for exactly the same reason, the countercyclicality through an economic cycle of a wholesale business versus a consumer business.

We've spent the last couple of years trying to defend a wholesale business, while a consumer business was enjoying the lowest unemployment rate in the UK and the US. If there is an economic slowdown, not that I'm hoping for one, it'll be nice to be watching the wholesale business perform relative to the consumer business and change the nature of the discussion. So it's that diversification of the revenue stream, which I think -- the economic cycles will be there, they will come back. We haven't solved that, and as you

Go through those economic cycles, I think the diversification of our model and being a universal bank will show its cards.

JASON MICHAEL GOLDBERG: One of the topics this morning, we didn't get really a touch on was -- is Brexit. Maybe you could share with us what's your best guess for what happens next? How is Barclays prepared? And then also maybe just talk to the impact on U.K. in terms of, I guess, potential of economic downturn, lower rates, increased competitive pressures from traditional and emerging competitors? Just how is Barclays U.K. positioned?

JAMES EDWARD STALEY: Well, Brexit, more than anything else, is challenging the political structure of the UK. It's a parliamentary government without a constitution. There are a lot of rules being written, and obviously, the inability to come to a consensus following the referendum vote is really challenging the political institutions of the United Kingdom. And as I think, you've seen in a lot of other countries, political institutions are under challenge. And so elections are very difficult to predict. But for sure, I think everyone is read -- is arriving at a level of frustration at the political uncertainty in the UK, which is not healthy.

In terms of the economic impact, personally, I think the economic impact has pretty much been felt. We have a much lower sterling. So on a purchasing power basis, everyone in the UK is less well off because of the uncertainty. We have had slower economic growth than some of the countries that you would compare us to. The Bank of England came out with a number saying they think that the amount of new investment in the U.K. is 11% lower over the last 3 years than otherwise would've been. It's very hard to prove the counterfactual, but I think we've felt a lot of the economic challenge of this uncertainty that we've been living through today.

Between a deal and a no-deal, I personally think that there'll be a medium and long-term impact between no-deal and a deal, and you can debate that. But I think the short-term impact, as you transition either through a deal or transition through a no-deal, it's not going to be as dramatic as some people are talking about, much like the short-term economic impact of the referendum vote was not what people expected. It was not the Armageddon.

The services industries like Barclays, we are a 100% ready whether it's a no-deal or deal or soft Brexit or hard Brexit. We have recapitalized our bank in Dublin, in Ireland. By the end of this year, we'll be the largest Bank in Ireland. We've taken all of our branches across Europe, and we have relicensed them to be branches of the bank in Ireland as opposed to the branches in England or in Great Britain. We have moved all the people that we're going to move. We have staffed all the desks. We've built all the models that we need to build. We're in a very good place with our regulators. And almost all of our clients that need to migrate to deal with us in the European context have migrated. So October 31st comes and goes. It will have almost zero impact on Barclays. And I think most of the service industry is in very similar shape.

In terms of the goods and the supply chain, what people know is, the UK is in a huge deficit in that position. We -- the United Kingdom imports many more goods than they export. There are 100,000 companies in France that export a product every day to United Kingdom. I don't think they're going to shut the border. The pain will be felt on the other side of the canal. Now -- so the uncertainty has created lack of investment, et cetera, but I think through a transition period, trade deals will be reached, and they'll find a mutually benefit outcome. In the long run, which is the better one, we will see.

I think the real issue is not between a Brexit and a hard Brexit, I think it's very likely that there is a general election sometime between here in the first quarter, unless somehow it gets pushed towards a new referendum. And that, a new referendum, personally, I think would be quite a challenge. But I think what everybody wants is to get uncertainty behind us. We're ready as a bank. We think most of our clients are ready, and I think we do have to get on with it.

JASON MICHAEL GOLDBERG: In answer to you -- in your answers to my diversification question, it sounded -- I heard a hint of optimism around the Corporate and Investment Bank. But how -- I guess what makes you confident about the outlook for the CIB industry, given the challenges that many had generating above cost of capital returns, particularly some of the smaller players? And what specific actions are you taking to improve our returns?

JAMES EDWARD STALEY: So I -- so to me, the primary regulatory response to the financial crisis was to rely less on bank balance sheets and what's called maturity transformation to generate economic growth than we had historically.

So if you look at Europe and United States, the amount of bank balance sheets financing businesses has actually in absolute terms declined over the last decade since the financial crisis.

On the flip side, what has replaced that is a belief that the capital markets do not impose the maturity transformation risk that bank balance sheets do. And therefore, let's rely on the capital markets in order to fund economic growth. And indeed, over the last decade, the capital markets have roughly doubled in size. So just as from the most macro level, if you want to be involved in financing economic growth in a developing market, I think you have to recognize that the regulatory stack now is built behind growing the capital markets and putting a limit on the growth of bank balance sheet. That's the first reason given that we want to stay close to our existing client base that staying in the capital markets as a bulge bracket bank is so important.

Now you have the influence of technology. And I think there is a race between the buy-side wanting to decrease their cost of transacting with the sell-side providing technology solutions that end up preserving the margins of the intermediaries, but at the same time, helping the cost base for the buy-side. And I think we're on that journey, and that's clearly something -- clearly, that it is something to watch.

The second thing is capacity is leaving the market. There are a lot of major players that have essentially decided to leave as intermediary in the capital markets. And the FT article the other day talking about will Barclays "Will be the last man standing?" There is capacity leaving and hopefully that is reflected in the economics for those that have decided to stick it out.

There are other things that are going on in the regulatory framework. Regulators love securities financing. So whether it's prime credit or prime equities, the calculation of risk-weighted asset for a broker-dealer extending credit to a buy-side firm collateralized by liquid securities is one of the most attractive risk weights in the industry. And I think a lot of what's driving those banks that are improving their profitability is around the prime services, which is, in some banks, it's 30%, 40% of their markets' revenues.

So the final point for me is, if you think about this as a long-term trend line and don't underestimate how dramatic the financial crisis was for the financial industry and how extraordinary the reregulation of the industry has been. You just take Barclays. Barclays, 10 years ago, our CET1 ratio against the risk of the bank was 4%. Our CET1 ratio now is effectively 14%. The calculation of risk-weighted assets back then -- the calculation of the risk-weighted asset 10 years ago, a AAA securities' risk weight was 0. A -- the risk-weighted assets of a 30-year interest rate swap with an acceptable ISDA was 0. Now we turn on the lights, and we have operational risk-weighted assets. If you take those 2 judgments -- or those 2 adjustments, CET1 capital and the calibration of risk, and it's no joke. 20% of the capital of Barclays is held against an operational risk, which is not an asset. The one thing I will guarantee you is the return on tangible equity, the 20% of our capital is 0. If you made the adjustments, roughly back then pro forma basis, Morgan's -- a Barclays' CIB was generating, let's say, 15%, 16% RoTE. You make the adjustment to capital, the exact same business, the exact same revenues, we will be over 60% today. So that's the trend line that's happening, and I think if you miss that trend line, by the time it catches up with you, you will have regretted that move.

And so one of the challenges or frustrating things is we've essentially taken the profitability of Barclays in the last 3 years from 5% to 9% and against a much higher capital base. So that in the first half of this year, as a statutory basis, this was the most profitable first 6 months of Barclays in over a decade. As I said, we moved our CET capital ratio. There's an adjustment that we're currently discussing with the PRA, but we would've landed at the midyear at 14%. The highest capital ratio this bank has had in anyone's recollection.

Then we took our dividend, and we've tripled it in 3 years. So that -- so we announced a new dividend policy at the annual results, that's the highest dividend that's paid -- this bank has paid in over 10 years. So we've gone through a massive restructuring. We have 56,000 less people. We're out of the continent of Africa. We sold 22 businesses. It's just a huge change, and it's one of the most profitable 6 months this bank has ever had. And our stock is 50% of book.

So we don't blame management, we blame everybody, no. So I feel that we like universal banking model. We like the trajectory of the Corporate and the Investment Bank. One of the things particular to Barclays that we've got a real focus on in getting real-time transaction, the most unprofitable thing we do at the bank is to extend an undrawn revolving line of credit. And you can track a client-by-client return on risk-weighted assets pretty easily. And our problem was, we had too many companies that we were extending undrawn revolvers to that weren't doing corollary transaction business with us, and that led us to have a return on risk-weighted assets, which was unacceptably low. Before we got here, that really wasn't a focus of the bank, it's a laser focus now. And we have made significant progress over the last couple of years of improving the rate of return on risk-weighted assets, by driving transactional business payments, foreign exchange, trade finance, et cetera, to support where we were extending undrawn lines of credit. And over a 2-year, we -- 2-year period, and we're well on track, we expect for our largest clients to double the return on risk-weighted asset that we're generating. So -- and that in turn will deliver comfortably a double-digit return from our corporate bank. So things like that are the progression, and I think that we're in a good place.

JASON MICHAEL GOLDBERG: One of the concerns we hear right here from global financial services' investors is about just a lower-for-longer rate outlook globally, how big of a challenge is that for Barclays?

JAMES EDWARD STALEY: It's a challenge in -- for all of us, but particularly for those countries like Japan and Europe that has -- seem to have lower, lower, lower for longer. But that being said, we have a great franchise in the U.K. around secured consumer lending and unsecured consumer lending. And our net interest margin is 300 basis points. I think I'd put that up against almost any bank. And what we've been doing since the referendum vote, we've been rebalancing our mix of unsecured to secured in order to improve -- or, in our own mind, reduce the potential risk of our U.K. consumer credit book. With interest rates coming down, and as we go through this uncertainty, and the position of the U.K. consumer is actually quite good, our impairment numbers are quite solid. We very well may -- are reflecting these lower interest rates begin to rebalance or unsecured with our concern. And that gives us the ability to preserve a degree of NIM. So you do have levers that you can push to manage through that.

The bigger challenge, I think, is less in your net interest margin as much as managing your overall liquidity. And that's where managing your liquidity in a cash environment, where you got to leave a certain amount of cash and hold government securities is tough when they are getting lower. But again, for us, that's why we like having such a significant part of our balance sheet in the U.K. I'd much rather have 140 basis points in the U.S. than negative 70 in Germany.

JASON MICHAEL GOLDBERG: Interesting. I guess one of the things you've been clear on, maybe too clear, is kind of cost control and the ability to manage expenses in terms of making sure Barclays has achieved its RoTE objectives. Can you maybe talk to your outlook on costs? And then when you were here 2 years ago, you spent a bit of time talking about the services company, which we now call BX, just what role did that play?

JAMES EDWARD STALEY: So on the cost side, we sat in March of 2016 and said, "We have to restructure the bank, reorganize the bank, deal with conduct and litigation issues." And at some point, we need to get the topic du jour, of the day, of PPI. And so we embarked upon a journey. We created our service company, which has about 55,000 of our 85,000 employees. We've created what are called transaction cycles, which are processes that cut across all of our lines of businesses but are similar processes like fraud. And what we've really done. If you sit back and look at the numbers for the last 3 years, we have improved our RoTE roughly from 5% to 9%. Half of that has come from roughly a GBP 1.5 billion decrease in our run rate expenses, and half of it has come from about GBP 1.5 billion in increases in revenues, by investing in technology and people, et cetera, et cetera. So roughly a 50-50 mix has allowed us to take our cost-income ratio from 73% -- or from 72% down to 63%. And if you look at that cost-to-income ratio compared with American banks, with the European banks, with big banks and small banks with model lines and online, that's a pretty good number. At 63%, we are in a pretty good place, actually. So that as I look forward to driving to the 10% RoTE and 11% RoTE, maintaining cost control is important. But we, as a management team, are beginning -- ever more thinking about, are we going to drive revenues? We're going to create new sources of revenues, we're going to improve our market share, our business mix, the efficiency of our capital use, but we don't want to drop down our cost by another GBP 1.5 billion.

What we're actually doing is, if you go back 2 years ago or even a year ago, most of our expenses were obligatory. We had to set up the ring-fence bank that cost GBP 1.4 billion in the U.K. We had to set up the IHC in United States that cost money. We had to set up the bank in Dublin for Brexit that cost money. We had to do a lot of things around the stability of our tech stack, so that we didn't go offline with any degree of regularity. Most of all of that is behind us. We have significantly decreased what we call the run-the-bank expense.

What we are doing now that we find our cost-to-income ratio in a more comfortable place, we are on target of improving the profitability as much as we've had to grow the bank. To invest technology spend for new algorithms and new trading platforms for technology to dramatically advance your client onboarding process. If you wanted to join our merchant acquiring platform a year ago, it would've taken you 5 weeks to get onboarded by our merchant acquiring business. We're now down to 1 day. And we want to get down to a function of minutes if we're going to compete with the fintechs. But that's growing your business, that allows us to add new small businesses that before we wouldn't have gotten it. And someone just opening a new online company is not going to wait for 5 weeks to get their online payment services done.

So we are investing to grow the business, we are digitizing the bank. We now have 8 million consumers that are banking through their mobile banking app with us exclusively that's growing 85,000 consumers a day. We now have open banking in the U.K. So through APIs, we can download 3x a day all your financial information in your Lloyds account and in your Royal Bank of Scotland account. So much so, if you like the value proposition of this bank 5 years ago was to get an 18-year-old walk into a branch, open a checking account and manage their financial life through that checking account. Now let's get the 18-year-old to go online and download the Barclays' app and manage their financial life through that, irrespective of whether the checking account is Lloyds or Barclays. And there's a massive difference between those 2 value propositions. The average customer walks into a bank branch once every 5 weeks. And they walk in, you have really no idea who they are. What they want to do, you really don't know until they click on. You may have an idea once they tell you who they are and what they're thinking about. You may have some system that tells a teller what's going on. The average consumer on the mobile banking app, they go on our site or on our app every day. And when they go on the app, we know exactly who they are. We know exactly what they've been doing. We have a pretty good idea actually what they're joining us all about. And the -- so the whole value proposition changes dramatically.

That's spending technology to grow the bank, that's what's so transformational about this versus 3 years ago when we were spending money to ring-fence the bank, to be compliant with new British regulation. So I feel good about that we now -- now the other benefit, when you do that spend for the ring-fence bank, you have no choice. It's going to be done by Easter 2018 or the British government is going to come down on you. So now we download a new version of the mobile app once every 7 days. We can roll that back to once every 8 days if we want to. It's a discretionary spend. So when we look at that GBP 13.5 billion, GBP 13.6 billion spend target, a lot of it is discretionary that we can dial up or dial down based on the performance of the bank.

And then for all those happy investment bankers here, we spent GBP 600 million in 2016 and '17 in order to bring forward the vesting of our bonus pool, so we can correlate our quarterly revenues with our quarterly compensation costs.

And I think just like an asset management business, you have to be able to regulate -- or manage your compensation expense with how you're doing in terms of alpha generation, et cetera, or your AUM numbers in order to have a more stabilized profit stream. And the same thing with the investment bank, and we believe that we can calibrate our bonus pool on a on-time basis, commensurate or correlated with our revenues. So we feel much more in control of the bank's cost base, and then as we look at that cost-to-income ratio, the solution now is not to continue this climb to knock down expenses, but rather to continue this new investment opportunity to grow revenues. And that's what's driving our belief that we'll get to 10% despite interest rates and that we'll continue to advance thereon.

JASON MICHAEL GOLDBERG: You've tucked on it for a second, but maybe we could delve more into payments. It's definitely a big focus of the investors that are here. Could you maybe talk to some of the changes to how consumer banking and payments is led at Barclays? You made some change there earlier in the year. And can you maybe talk a bit about your view of the opportunities that Barclays has? And just how you think about a bank-owned payment business can succeed against some of these pure-play companies?

JAMES EDWARD STALEY: Before I get to payments, let me just -- because I keep forgetting to -- which is we did an RNS a little bit ago for those who didn't see it, announcing our PPI expense range for the third quarter on the back of August, which was the last month for PPI claims in the United Kingdom. We predicted that a -- our claims will fall somewhere between GBP 1.2 billion and GBP 1.6 billion. Out there is what Lloyds is going to do and Royal Bank of Scotland. So that's range PPI ended at the end of August, so this is the last present from PPI. What I would say is that's probably about 40 to 50 basis points of CET1 ratio. We are -- remember, we closed the interims at 13.4% with our target at 13%. And so we're very comfortable that with current dividend policy in place, we will still easily land our end state capital CET1 ratio despite what we saw PPI today. So I just want to get that all out and clear. Hopefully, I believe I said it the right way.

Your question was?

JASON MICHAEL GOLDBERG: Payments?

JAMES EDWARD STALEY: Payments. So payments, I think, is the battlefield of finance for the next decade. And the players are clearly not just the banks. The players -- it is the vertical that the fintech players are most interested in. It is ultimately where the big tech players are going to get closer and closer to, whether it's Amazon, whether it's Facebook, creating a cryptocurrency for Facebook in Switzerland is a fascinating idea. But -- so I think the payment space is real.

And it's very important for, I think, a successful bank to maintain and manage the position we have across payments. In the U.K., a very big deal now is the degree of authentication that a consumer has to go through to allow a digital payment. We think we have certain competitive advantages because of our technology stack and what we're doing in this around the ability to authenticate who is making a payment. That's a big deal vis-Ã -vis fraud in the U.K. We, right now, have a payments platform that we think is a competitive advantage if and when we wanted to partner with a big tech company. So there are possibilities there.

And then for us, we have this platform idea where we have 8 million consumers banking with us on the Barclays app, growing at the rate it's growing. 36% of all merchandised sales in the U.K. goes across our merchant acquiring business. So can we take the relationship we have with our merchants on that app and combine it with the interest and desires of our consumers and create a platform that is around that payment space, which gives us a sustainable competitive advantage. There is no bank that has a merchant acquiring business like ours. There is no merchant acquiring business that has a mobile app like we do. So payments is a very big deal. I do think it's a war -- or the battleground of finance for the next decade, but I feel very confident about where we sit.

JASON MICHAEL GOLDBERG: While I pull up here, we can maybe open up to the audience for questions.

JAMES EDWARD STALEY: That's a warning, if you ask a question though.

JASON MICHAEL GOLDBERG: Just while the audience is thinking of questions, I guess maybe shift gears and talk about the regulatory environment. How do you see that evolving from here for Barclays?

JAMES EDWARD STALEY: Well, we have said almost since day 1 of the Brexit, we think the Bank of England, what we need to be focused on is to maintain a competitiveness with the U.S. Given our business model and given that our role of wholesale banking, one of the reasons why Brexit didn't really worry me vis-Ã -vis a bank in the U.K. or a bank like us because we are less a function of equivalency with Brussels and much more important for us is equivalency with Washington and the New York Fed.

I think that the regulatory invasion of finance was very much needed. And I think we need to appreciate the fact that a lot of what we're doing in the banking industry created enormous economic destruction and a more proximate relationship between the regulators and those that are regulated was very much necessary.

I think what you're seeing in the U.S., and I think in a reasonably intelligent way, it's sort of a recalibration. I think from Randy Quarles to the Secretary of Treasury, they are, at the margins, trying to recalibrate the regulatory environment in the U.S., and I think that's a healthy thing. I don't think you throw out things like the Volcker Rule or whatnot. You cannot -- I don't believe you just swing the pendulum back to any significant degree, but some recalibration is right. And I think the Europeans are catching up to that as well. And we have a great regulatory relationship with the Bank of England, the PRA and the FCA. In many times, they have been very constructive with us in terms of helping us think about strategically what direction or operationally our controls we should use to manage the bank better.

Though, I think going back to your issue about payments and big tech and fintech, there are costs of being a massively regulated financial institution. But today, one thing that will cost -- stop Amazon at the door is, he's not going to become a G-SIFI. And so regulation is both a challenge, but to a certain extent is also walling off the banking industry. And hopefully, it shouldn't be done too much because we don't want to be insulated to that degree. But I think a lot of progress has been made around regulation.

Going back to where I started, we have significantly and dramatically improved the profitability of this bank under much higher capital levels and much stronger risk-weight calibrations. And I think that trend is going to continue. We're at a 9% RoTE. We don't have a strategic challenge. We want to execute better, and we will do that. But this is a really profitable bank, after years of massive reorganization and the reregulation of the industry. And I feel really good about where we are. I feel really good where the industry is going to be, and I would make my own view, and we talked about this inside of our -- inside of risk committee and with regulators. I think the next financial crisis will most likely emanate outside of the banking, and that's something for all of us to think about.

JASON MICHAEL GOLDBERG: Any questions from the audience? Jeff?

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Jes, thanks for your comments. There's a question, maybe I'd be interested to hearing about your U.S., (inaudible) I'd be interested to hear about how (inaudible) and also your -- where you're going to take market share in (inaudible)?

JAMES EDWARD STALEY: Yes, I think we've been refining. I think there's been a little bit of push and a pause. What is working very well for us is the co-brand card space. And strategically, what we have done is when we co-brand with an American Airlines or an Uber or a JetBlue, what co-brand means for us is not to have both brands in the front of the card. The co-brand, for us means it's an American Airlines card. It's an Uber card. Because we don't have a sizable Barclays card, we're not in competition with those people that we co-brand with. And I don't think -- I'm not sure that's where Chase is or MedExpress is. That strategic pivot is a very valuable asset as we build the co-brand space.

And what we're basically saying is, we want to build our unsecured consumer loan book in the United States, not off the Barclays brand, which would be extremely expensive to create on a national scale, but on the brand of the American Airlines. So we have 11 million consumers in the United States that use a Barclays credit today, in part because of loyalty with another brand. And we want to continue to drive that. And I think you'll see a lot of things happening in that space.

What that has meant is we are -- we have slowed down the building of a Barclays-branded digital consumer bank, not because we don't think that technically we can get there. Because what we have in the U.K., we do, obviously, believe that we can get there. But more, do you want to spend the marketing dollars to do that and scale? And that's a question we're dealing with now. But we love the U.S. consumer business. One thing I would say that I think, almost every credit card company in the world is thinking about and getting involved in is point-of-sale financing and installment lending. One of the things that we're learning from millennials, whether they're here in the U.S. or in the U.K. or Germany for that matter where we have a bigger -- we have the largest credit card in Germany, is millennials somewhat reluctant to pay the high interest rates of a revolving line of credit for them. They don't really like paying cash, they love paying over installment. So we -- right now, we are the bank behind 1 out of every 4 iPhones sold in the United Kingdom, and that's because you get to buy your iPhone over 10 installments. That's a very attractive product for that client segment. So that is another evolution I think of -- I think you'll see credit cards increasingly looking at the installment loan market.

JASON MICHAEL GOLDBERG: Any questions? If not, please join me in thanking Jes for his time today.

block-time published-time 8.41am BST

I just received a government media release titled 'siding with those who produce our food' and really, I can't think of a better way to wrap up the blog.

That's it for the next five weeks. The parliament is officially on winter break and won't return until 9 September. That is not to say that there won't be news. Mike Pompeo is coming to town, ahead of Scott Morrison's visit to the US next month, where he will be treated to a state dinner. The Liberal executive will be meeting tomorrow, where it will discuss how it has dealt with bullying complaints, and worst, in the past.

And there's also the small matter of building a legislative agenda.

Labor's review into what went wrong with the election is ongoing, with the final report to be handed down in October. But those talks and meetings are happening now, so stay tuned on that.

And the court of disputed returns will hear the petitions against the Kooyong and Chisholm elections - at least directions. The high court will be sitting for three of the next five weeks, which makes it a very strong chance you'll hear something.

So we hope you will keep popping back and checking the site for all your usual political news.

A very, very big thank you to Mike Bowers, who you'll find on Talking Pictures each Sunday, and cameo-ing on Pyjama Politics, Katharine Murphy, Paul Karp and Sarah Martin for all their work this last sitting, as well as the rest of the Guardian's brains trust, who you don't hear from, but stop me from setting my desk on fire each and every day.

As always, the biggest thank you goes to you all. I'll miss you over the next month, but I hope you take a bit of time to cocoon yourselves. The new normal seems to be settling in and soon we are going to be at the end of the year, wondering how we got to 2020 quite so quickly. Stay warm, even those of you in the greatest nation of earth, Queensland, where I know the Ekka Westerlies are about to start blowing.

See you soon. In the mean time - take care of you.

block-time updated-timeUpdated at 8.52am BST

block-time published-time 8.16am BST

From Mike Bowers's eyeball to your eyeball.

My two moods. Photograph: Mike Bowers/The Guardian Scott Morrison during question time in the House of Representatives. Photograph: Mike Bowers/The Guardian #welldoneAngus Photograph: Mike Bowers/The Guardian Barnaby does Barnaby. Photograph: Mike Bowers/The Guardian

block-time updated-timeUpdated at 8.36am BST

block-time published-time 8.06am BST

The House has just adjourned and the Senate looks close.

The rush to the airport has begun.

block-time published-time 7.57am BST

After question time, Mathias Cormann gave a brief and un-illuminating statement about the Crown casino matter.

He said the government takes "allegations of illegal activity very seriously" which is why the attorney general has referred "allegations of corruption involving the Home Affairs Department and Crown casino to the Australian Commission for Law Enforcement Integrity".

"I can also advise - the prime minister is not aware of any of his ministers breaching ministerial standards in relation to this matter."

Greens senator Nick McKim said that Cormann had failed to answer the question of whether the prime minister has investigated the claims that two ministers lobbied Home Affairs to "grease the wheels" for Crown casino high-rollers.

"All we got was the insulting platitude that the PM is 'not aware'," he said.

Greens senator Larissa Waters also had a swing, but no Labor senators did the same.

block-time updated-timeUpdated at 7.59am BST

block-time published-time 7.33am BST

Christian Porter has also responded to Labor's calls to bring forward the federal integrity commission. His statement:

Hypocrisy and double standards are what we have come to expect from the Labor party.

But Mark Dreyfus sunk to new lows even for himself today when he accused the government of dragging its heels on the delivery of a Commonwealth Integrity Commission (CIC).

To set the record straight, the Coalition - unlike Labor - has actually been doing the hard work necessary to deliver a carefully considered and properly funded watchdog since we first committed to establishing a CIC in December last year.

Attorney general Christian Porter said a draft bill was already being finalised, which would form the basis of public consultation and the final Bill would be completed by the end of the year.

'Our CIC will be properly designed and subject to a robust consultation phase," Mr Porter said.

'It has $106.7m of new money allocated to it in the current budget over the forward estimates, plus:

$40.7m in existing funding for the Australian Commission for Law Enforcement Integrity, which will work alongside the CIC.

'In contrast, Labor has released what amounts to little more than a press release containing a vague set of design principles and a suggestion that $58.7 million would be enough to cover the costs. That is $89 million less than we have committed.

'But what is most hypocritical is that Labor was willing to allow itself a full year to draft their CIC legislation, had they won the election.

'Now all of a sudden they are attacking in the parliament their own reasonable time frame for properly developing and consulting on complex legislation in this important area of law.

'The reason why this legislation cannot be rushed should be obvious to Mr Dreyfus given the many examples of injustices and damage done to personal and professional reputations when the necessary time and care was not taken to properly design state-based integrity commissions.

'Labor might not care about hurting innocent people but the Morrison government does and we will not be lectured by hypocrites seeking to waste the parliament's time to score cheap political points.

block-time updated-timeUpdated at 7.43am BST

block-time published-time 7.30am BST

The Law Council is not overly impressed with the passage of the latest national security bill, given the concerns that have been raised over it. From its statement:

The Law Council has grave concerns Asio's Questioning and Detention Warrant (QDW) powers have been extended for a further 12 months without clear justification.

These are some of the most far-reaching and extraordinary powers granted to any intelligence organisation in a western democracy and should be repealed. They give Asio the power to secretly and immediately detain persons whether or not they are suspected of terrorism-related activities.

While the Law Council understands and supports our national security agencies possessing the necessary powers required to prevent threats and keep the community safe, these must always be reasonable and proportionate in order to safeguard the rights of innocent Australians if such powers are mistakenly used or abused.

The QDW powers have never been exercised. It is not clear to the Law Council why these laws remain [afoot] when there are other wide-ranging powers that Asio and other agencies possess.

The Law Council is concerned these provisions may be unconstitutional and a breach of Australia's international human rights obligations.

block-time updated-timeUpdated at 7.40am BST

block-time published-time 7.22am BST

Anthony Albanese concludes his speech with:

We on this side of the House are united. We know exactly what the values of the Labor party are, we know what they stand for: a strong economy and jobs. We know we stand for social justice.

We know we stand for lifting people up, not leaving people behind. We know we stand for engagement on the environment. Australians don't want that much and they don't ask that much from the government, but they expect a bit of respect.

They expect that the government will actually have a plan. And a third-term government should have developed that plan into a coherent narrative. Yet what we see is more and more scare campaigns.

The fact is that Labor's values are shared not just by people who have a common interest, who are united not just because we happen to be in parliament, and not just because we happen to be in the Labor party, but because it is our shared values that [brought us to the] Labor party, a party that has been in existence since 1891, a party that has proud origins and a proud history, a party that will continue to contribute to this nation's history into the future.

So I say to the prime minister: you ask the question, consider it answered. We on this side of the House know exactly who side we are on. On that side of the House, they are so divided that they can't even get an answer from a prime minister about senior members of the Liberal party and the National party appearing on the same platform with extreme rightwing ideologues in order to promote division in this country, allowing the sort of talk that will just divide us.

I will conclude with the prime minister's question.

We know exactly who we are and we know whose side we are on. We are the Australian Labor party, and we are on the side of Australia's national interests. It's a pity that there is a government that isn't, that is just on the side of its own selfish political interests, and [which] seeks to divide people, promote fear and engage in negative politics because they don't have a positive agenda for the third term.

block-time updated-timeUpdated at 7.28am BST

block-time published-time 7.21am BST

Albanese:

We on this side of the House to support a voice for First Nations people in our Constitution. Those opposite have roadblocks in their cabinet like the Minister for Home Affairs, who walked out on the apology. We on this side of the House understand that you can protect your borders without losing your humanity; those opposite have engaged in dehumanising people in our care for political gain. We on the side of the House appeal to hope; those on that side of the House rely upon fear. We want to shape the future in the interests of all Australians; those opposite are frightened of the present and terrified of the future.

Nowhere is that better characterised than in the NBN: we understand that fibre is the technology of the 21st century; those opposite rely on copper to go forward.

We on this side one genuine support for our farmers who are struggling in the drought, who need action on climate change, who need real funding; those opposite want legislation that gives them some money in the following financial year-$100 million rather than the $5 billion that they talk about.

We on this side of House are absolutely determined to bring the nation together.

We reject those who seek to divide us.

And the fact that in their No. 1 talking point, from the Prime Minister, to the Treasurer and to the Minister opposite, they talk about 'Whose side are you on?'

Shows exactly what they are about. They don't have a positive agenda, they rely upon negative politics and they seek to divide at every single opportunity.

block-time published-time 7.20am BST

Albanese continued:

We support those who are struggling and who need a helping hand. Those opposite say that people have never been better off, in spite of the reports just this week. We understand that free markets left alone, because they have no conscience, entrench existing relationships of power, both economic and social. Those opposite still support trickle-down economics. They say it will all be okay if government just gets out of the way. We understand that unions have a critical role in a democratic society. Those opposite just want to attack them. We understand the importance of holding business to account, which is why we supported the banking royal commission at the same time as they voted against it 26 times. We support building infrastructure; they support talking about building infrastructure. We respect public servants; they cut public servants. We respect the science of climate change; those opposite want equal time for climate sceptics to teach in the classroom. We regard education as being about creating opportunity; those opposite see it as just entrenching privilege.

We support Medicare being at the heart of the health system. Those opposite undermine it at every opportunity. We support increasing Newstart. Those opposite regard that as just 'unfunded empathy'. We support addressing homelessness. They want more positive spin about homelessness, to talk about the 99 per cent who are in homes rather than the one per cent who are homeless. We support pensioners. Those opposite say that the pension is too generous. We support aged care that looks after our vulnerable older Australians. Those opposite want to get rid of regulation and just let the market rip. We support superannuation as being critical for our nation. Those opposite undermine it. We support a free media. Those opposite have engaged in cynical, politically motivated raids and intimidation against journalists.

block-time published-time 7.20am BST

Anthony Albanese:

Just a few weeks ago we all stood in this House and debated the passing of Bob Hawke, a great Australian who stood for all Australians. Bob Hawke's prime ministership was characterised by an understanding that together we are stronger. He looked for common ground. Nothing could stand in more contrast with that than what we've seen from this government in its three-week self-indulgent vanity project, this victory lap where it has brought parliament back in July.

The fact is that the prime minister is in search of an agenda. In place of that, he's chosen division. He characterises that himself when he stands in parliament and has the talking points for all the ministers about, 'Whose side are you on?'

I've had a chat to a few constitutional experts about whether parliament itself can resolve eligibility questions, in the context of news a constituent has challenged treasurer Josh Frydenberg in the court of disputed returns.

It's a little known fact that section 47 of the constitution contains a power for the houses of parliament to determine eligibility and deal with disputed elections - but it is subject to the qualification "until parliament otherwise provides".

Professor Tony Blackshield told Guardian Australia the houses of parliament "no longer have exclusive power" - because they have passed legislation allowing challenges to the court - "but they still do have the power". For example, in 1999 the House of Representatives declined to refer Warren Entsch to the high court over an alleged pecuniary interest, and instead resolved itself that he was eligible.

Professor Anne Twomey thinks it's "a very hard question" to resolve. On one view parliament has decided to confer jurisdiction on the court, and limited its own jurisdiction. But on the other hand, Twomey points to some observations by three justices in Sue v Hill which suggest it could be possible that the court and parliament could come into conflict, offering contradictory views on the eligibility of a member or senator.

Twomey: " Even if the House did retain jurisdiction to decide the issue, there is also the convention of 'sub judice' in parliament. That is that the Houses should not debate things that are currently before the courts. It would hence be most inappropriate for a House to decide on a Member's qualification or disqualification once proceedings have been initiated in the court of disputed returns. It would also show a lack of respect for the judicial process. Hence, I don't think it likely that the House would do so."

In any event - the government does not seem keen to try to resolve the issue in parliament.

Attorney general Christian Porter said:

"All Coalition candidates at the last election were subject to rigorous eligibility checks.

The government is confident in its members' eligibility and does not need to move a motion on the floor of the House to resolve the issue."

The home affairs department is keeping a multimillion-dollar strategic review into Peter Dutton's super portfolio secret from the public.

The review was ordered just five months after the creation of the home affairs department in late 2017, which saw the former department of immigration and border protection expanded with agencies and responsibilities from within the attorney general's department, as well as elements of regional development, social services and prime minister and cabinet.

The community has the right to know how one of our largest government departments - and one that is so fundamental to our national security - is being administered.

Meanwhile, the government is pushing new legislation to keep "high-risk terrorist offenders" in prison, beyond any sentence they may be handed "if they pose an ongoing threat to public safety".

There's no information yet on who judges who is an ongoing threat, or what constitutes that ongoing threat. From Christian Porter's office:

The changes were recommended by the Council of Australian Governments following a deadly 2017 terror attack in Victoria, which involved an offender who was on bail and had previously been charged with a terrorism offence.

The community was rightly outraged by Yacqub Khayre's case and I believe the changes we are introducing today strike the right balance between protecting individual rights and freedoms, and protecting the community.

Plus, there is the ensuring integrity bill heading to the Senate. But that doesn't have the numbers with the crossbench as yet, so it is doubtful it will go anywhere before the break.

You have Mike Bowers, Katharine Murphy, Paul Karp and me, who is at least at 15% capacity, so huzzah for that.

Also - happy horse birthday.

Ready?

Let's get into it.

urn:contentItem:5R0D-DHC1-JCJY-G205-00000-00Baroness (Beeban) Kidron vows: 'We'll stop the tech giants treating kids like clickbait'2017-11-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:34ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:1Baroness (Beeban) Kidron vows: 'We'll stop the tech giants treating kids like clickbait'Danny Fortson

Silicon Valley's tech giants face a global crackdown on how they target children online, predicts Baroness (Beeban) Kidron, author of a child protection amendment to the upcoming data protection bill.

In a hard-hitting interview for The Sunday Times's Danny in the Valley podcast, Kidron, 56, said that Big Tech treated kids like "click-bait". She added: "It's becoming intolerable to a lot of people."

The film maker, who joined the House of Lords as a crossbencher in 2012, has proposed an amendment that calls for minimum requirements of "age-appropriate design" of websites and apps. This would encompass measures from enhanced privacy settings to limiting push notifications and making terms and conditions clear to young people. The amendment is supported by the NSPCC and the Children's Society, as well as former TalkTalk chief executive Baroness (Dido) Harding.

Kidron's proposals would come on top of other regulations in the data protection bill, including one that would make it illegal for internet companies to knowingly sign up people younger than 13 to their services. A vote could some as early as mid-December.

Kidron, a children's rights advocate who directed a documentary about children online called In Real Life, said the tech industry has made a "category error" by treating children the same as adults, tracking their activity and building profiles in hopes of altering their behaviour and serving them highly targeted ads. She said: "It's a catastrophe that we have a technology that . . . [could] remedy some of the greatest ills of the world, and we have a corporate culture so set against upholding its societal responsibilities."

The aim of her proposals, she argued, is to make the digital world reflect the real world, where children are afforded protections and services that reflect their age. "This is not actually even about content, particularly. It's actually about the orchestrated technology that is treating a child like a data centre instead of like a child."

Kidron said she had long been a "voice in the woods" on the issue but had sensed a change recently. "I'm now a choir in the woods . . . It's going to be a tipping point and we will get fundamental reform much quicker than other people think."

At The Times and Sunday Times Tech Summit last week, Matt Hancock, the digital minister, said the government was committed to making the internet a "safe and happy place" for children, but that Kidron's amendment was "clunky and effectively unworkable".

urn:contentItem:5VJH-BXK1-JD3S-J3KS-00000-00Baroness Massey: We must equip young people to make sensible choices about use of the internet and to have the skills to combat bad influence2019-02-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:34ZLexisNexisBaroness Massey: We must equip young people to make sensible choices about use of the internet and to have the skills to combat bad influence

Labour peer Baroness Massey of Darwen writes following her House of Lords question on 'Strengthening controls over internet providers in the light of concerns over child bullying and suicide'.

In the House of Lords this week, two pieces of business in the House of Lords Chamber focused on children's safety and well -being. Firstly, a statement on the proposals for draft regulations and guidance on for relationships education, relationships and sex education and health education. The second was my oral question to ask the Government what action they are taking, in the light of concerns over child bullying and suicide arising from online activity, to strengthen controls over internet providers.

These two examples complement each other. I asked, in my supplementary question to the Minister, if the Government recognised that the protection of children is half the problem, empowering them to be resilient and aware of danger of the internet is also important.

The Minister, Lord Ashton, acknowledged that the Government has a duty to make sure that social media and big tech companies are held to account. There will be on online harms White paper to support this. He also acknowledged the importance of dealing with safety online in schools.

The NSPCC and other charities in the online safety alliance have expressed concerns for many years about control of the internet in order to keep children safe, including age verification. We know that the media consistently reports report self harm, suicide, bullying and other terrible things happening to children. The finger is often pointed at the content of some online presentations. Parents are in despair about this phenomenon, and feel helpless in tackling this, to them, mysterious and harmful influence.

An NSPCC survey has found that six out of ten parents do not think that social networks protect their children from inappropriate content. Nine out of ten of parents support the regulation of social networks to make then legally responsible for protecting children. The NSPCC's Wild West campaign is calling on Government to introduce a social media regulator.

The problem is difficult to police and the big four companies have grown to enormous sizes. The problem needs to be firmly tackled both in relation to child protection and in equipping young people to be able to make sensible choices about use of the internet and to have the skills to combat bad influence. There is a good case, also, for raising the awareness of parents and carers to the dangers which may be involved.

Baroness Massey of Darwen is a Labour peer

Labour peer Baroness Massey of Darwen writes following her House of Lords question on 'Strengthening controls over internet providers in the light of concerns over child bullying and suicide'.

In the House of Lords this week, two pieces of business in the House of Lords Chamber focused on children's safety and well -being. Firstly, a statement on the proposals for draft regulations and guidance on for relationships education, relationships and sex education and health education. The second was my oral question to ask the Government what action they are taking, in the light of concerns over child bullying and suicide arising from online activity, to strengthen controls over internet providers.

These two examples complement each other. I asked, in my supplementary question to the Minister, if the Government recognised that the protection of children is half the problem, empowering them to be resilient and aware of danger of the internet is also important.

The Minister, Lord Ashton, acknowledged that the Government has a duty to make sure that social media and big tech companies are held to account. There will be on online harms White paper to support this. He also acknowledged the importance of dealing with safety online in schools.

The NSPCC and other charities in the online safety alliance have expressed concerns for many years about control of the internet in order to keep children safe, including age verification. We know that the media consistently reports report self harm, suicide, bullying and other terrible things happening to children. The finger is often pointed at the content of some online presentations. Parents are in despair about this phenomenon, and feel helpless in tackling this, to them, mysterious and harmful influence.

An NSPCC survey has found that six out of ten parents do not think that social networks protect their children from inappropriate content. Nine out of ten of parents support the regulation of social networks to make then legally responsible for protecting children. The NSPCC's Wild West campaign is calling on Government to introduce a social media regulator.

The problem is difficult to police and the big four companies have grown to enormous sizes. The problem needs to be firmly tackled both in relation to child protection and in equipping young people to be able to make sensible choices about use of the internet and to have the skills to combat bad influence. There is a good case, also, for raising the awareness of parents and carers to the dangers which may be involved.

Baroness Massey of Darwen is a Labour peer

Labour peer Baroness Massey of Darwen writes following her House of Lords question on 'Strengthening controls over internet providers in the light of concerns over child bullying and suicide'.

In the House of Lords this week, two pieces of business in the House of Lords Chamber focused on children's safety and well -being. Firstly, a statement on the proposals for draft regulations and guidance on for relationships education, relationships and sex education and health education. The second was my oral question to ask the Government what action they are taking, in the light of concerns over child bullying and suicide arising from online activity, to strengthen controls over internet providers.

These two examples complement each other. I asked, in my supplementary question to the Minister, if the Government recognised that the protection of children is half the problem, empowering them to be resilient and aware of danger of the internet is also important.

The Minister, Lord Ashton, acknowledged that the Government has a duty to make sure that social media and big tech companies are held to account. There will be on online harms White paper to support this. He also acknowledged the importance of dealing with safety online in schools.

The NSPCC and other charities in the online safety alliance have expressed concerns for many years about control of the internet in order to keep children safe, including age verification. We know that the media consistently reports report self harm, suicide, bullying and other terrible things happening to children. The finger is often pointed at the content of some online presentations. Parents are in despair about this phenomenon, and feel helpless in tackling this, to them, mysterious and harmful influence.

An NSPCC survey has found that six out of ten parents do not think that social networks protect their children from inappropriate content. Nine out of ten of parents support the regulation of social networks to make then legally responsible for protecting children. The NSPCC's Wild West campaign is calling on Government to introduce a social media regulator.

The problem is difficult to police and the big four companies have grown to enormous sizes. The problem needs to be firmly tackled both in relation to child protection and in equipping young people to be able to make sensible choices about use of the internet and to have the skills to combat bad influence. There is a good case, also, for raising the awareness of parents and carers to the dangers which may be involved.

Baroness Massey of Darwen is a Labour peer

Labour peer Baroness Massey of Darwen writes following her House of Lords question on 'Strengthening controls over internet providers in the light of concerns over child bullying and suicide'.

In the House of Lords this week, two pieces of business in the House of Lords Chamber focused on children's safety and well -being. Firstly, a statement on the proposals for draft regulations and guidance on for relationships education, relationships and sex education and health education. The second was my oral question to ask the Government what action they are taking, in the light of concerns over child bullying and suicide arising from online activity, to strengthen controls over internet providers.

These two examples complement each other. I asked, in my supplementary question to the Minister, if the Government recognised that the protection of children is half the problem, empowering them to be resilient and aware of danger of the internet is also important.

The finger is often pointed at the content of some online presentations. Parents are in despair about this phenomenon, and feel helpless in tackling this, to them, mysterious and harmful influence.

An NSPCC survey has found that six out of ten parents do not think that social networks protect their children from inappropriate content. Nine out of ten of parents support the regulation of social networks to make then legally responsible for protecting children. The NSPCC's Wild West campaign is calling on Government to introduce a social media regulator.

The problem is difficult to police and the big four companies have grown to enormous sizes. The problem needs to be firmly tackled both in relation to child protection and in equipping young people to be able to make sensible choices about use of the internet and to have the skills to combat bad influence. There is a good case, also, for raising the awareness of parents and carers to the dangers which may be involved.

Baroness Massey of Darwen is a Labour peer

urn:contentItem:5XYW-HPS1-DYR7-80D7-00000-00Barrage of Big Tech Probes Is Unprecedented, Experts Say2019-12-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:34ZLexisNexisPg. A12Barrage of Big Tech Probes Is Unprecedented, Experts SayBowen XiaoNew York (NY)

"Big tech" faced an unprecedented number of antitrust investigations in 2019, with four major multinational technology companies-Facebook, Google, Amazon, and Apple-receiving a level of scrutiny that hasn't been seen in decades.

A congressional committee and subcommittee are investigating all four, even as the Justice Department (DOJ) and the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) are reviewing one or more of the companies. The probes extend down to the state level as well, with dozens of state attorneys general scrutinizing the practices of Facebook and Google in separate cases.

The barrage of investigations comes amid broad concerns about the effects of the "Big Four" on competition and consumers. The last time that both state and federal levels were investigating a case such as this was in 2001-the United States v. Microsoft Corp. case involving the latter's alleged monopoly on the PC market. Those probes, however, were only focused on one company.

"If it's not unprecedented, it's something that hasn't happened in many decades," John E. Lopatka, an antitrust scholar and a distinguished professor of law at Pennsylvania State University's Dickinson School of Law, told The Epoch Times.

"It is unusual in terms of both the scope and number of companies under investigation, as well as the intensity of the investigation," Lopatka, who previously served as the assistant director for planning for the Bureau of Competition at the FTC, said in a phone call. "I don't think we've seen anything like that in at least the last 50, 60 years."

The House Judiciary Committee is expected to complete a final report on its findings by the "first part" of 2020, the committee's chairman, Rep. David Cicilline (D-R.I.), told reporters on Oct. 18. Leaders of the committee and its subcommittee on antitrust have demanded the four companies turn over a wide range of documents including sensitive internal emails from the companies' top executives as well as detailed financial information, among other company records.

Meanwhile, Attorney General William Barr said on Dec. 10 he hoped to have the DOJ investigations completed "some time next year." In July, the department announced that its antitrust division is "reviewing whether and how market-leading online platforms have achieved market power and are engaging in practices that have reduced competition, stifled innovation, or otherwise harmed consumers."

The DOJ said it will probe concerns related to "search, social media, and some retail services online."

"It's been moving very quickly," Barr told the Wall Street Journal CeO Council. "We're talking very broadly with people and getting a lot of input from people in the industry and experts and so forth."

"I'd like to have it completed some time next year. I think it's important to move quickly on things," Barr continued. "These things have a cost to the marketplace and businesses. I think at some point, the government has to fish or cut bait."

At an early hearing of the antitrust panel in July, executives of the four companies pushed back against lawmakers' accusations that they operate as monopolies, laying out ways in which they say they compete fairly, yet vigorously, against rivals in the marketplace. Cicilline said he was dissatisfied with answers the executives gave to lawmakers, calling their testimony "evasive."

It's "very unusual" to have simultaneous investigations by the DOJ and the FTC, Eleanor Fox, professor of trade regulation at New York University School of Law, told The Epoch Times. The state-level probes are equally unconventional, added Fox, who is an expert in antitrust policy.

"It's not unusual that you have state attorneys general that are also investigating, but it's very unusual that you have so many of them on board for investigating," she said. "But the most unusual thing is the FTC and the DOJ are apparently investigating the same thing at the same time."

The attorneys general of 48 states, plus the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico, have opened an antitrust probe into Google and the company's "potential monopolistic behavior." The investigation is being led by Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton, who formally made the announcement on Sept. 9.

At the same time, a probe of Facebook led by New York has since expanded to include attorneys general from 47 U.S. states and territories.

It's not just agencies within the United States that are scrutinizing big tech behavior. Antitrust regulators from the EU are considering taking a tougher stance against the Big Four, Cecilio Madero Villarejo, acting director-general of the European Commission's competition division said in October.

Traditionally, the commission has just ordered companies to stop their anticompetitive practices but Villarejo said that may not be enough:

"In fast-moving markets, there is a risk that this would take too long to implement and be too difficult to monitor," Villarejo told a CRA conference.

Potential Actions

Rohit Chopra, an FTC commissioner, said at an October hearing that vast troves of consumer data collected by big tech allow them to gain a competitive edge and pose a threat to competition, by creating market entry barriers. Personal data is powering the dominance of tech companies that offer "free" basic services that are, ultimately, not free, he said.

Chopra also said the usual financial penalties won't be enough to address concerns over the power of big tech firms, adding that regulators will need to take a closer look.

New York attorney Barry Barnett, who has expertise in antitrust law, told The Epoch Times in September that the House probe could "potentially bring enforcement actions to halt or reverse acquisitions if they have created or sustained monopolies or aimed to do so."

Barnett also wondered if investigators are interested in moving away from a "narrow consumer-welfare approach" to one of "antitrust enforcement."

President Donald Trump, in the meantime, has accused big tech companies such as Facebook and Google of suppressing and censoring political speech, particularly conservative speech.

The timing of the new probes is interesting, New York-based corporate attorney Manny Alicandro told The Epoch Times previously. The vocal and online pressure from Trump against big tech is "making it newsworthy to the extent that it's very topical." But Alicandro also stressed that the probes are based on merit and should "not be viewed as politically motivated."

"This is historic scrutiny, because it's bipartisan," Alicandro said. "There's a lot at stake in terms of how much these entities-these big tech companies-control and how they disseminate information."

"Depending on the results ... it could have a material impact on these companies right now and similar companies going forward," he added.

California Attorney General Xavier Becerra told Reuters in October that his agency is concerned about corporate consolidation. His state is leading a fight to stop T-Mobile US from buying Sprint. If states can successfully block such deals, he said it would send a message that "antitrust enforcers will be back in the driver's seat."

It is unusual in terms of both the scope and number of companies under investigation, as well as the intensity of the investigation.
